sen.j: 上方舞（かみがたまい）とは、江戸時代中期（1800年）から末期にかけて上方で発生した、日本舞踊の一種。
sen.e: Kamigatamai is a type of Japanese dance emerged in Kyoto middle (1800) to end of Edo era.
Kamigatamai is a type of Japanese dance that emerged in Kyoto in the middle (1800) to the end of the Edo era.
Kamigatamai is a type of Japanese dance that emerged in Kyoto from 1800, in the middle of the Edo period, to the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 着流しに、屏風を立てた座敷で舞う素踊りを基本とする。
sen.e: Kamigatamai is based on suodori (dance without costume and hairpieces), in which dancers are dressed casually in kimono and dance in a Japanese style tatami room with folding screens.
Kamigatamai is based on suodori (dance without costume and hairpieces), in which dancers are dressed casually in kimono and dance in a Japanese style tatami room with folding screens.
Kamigatamai is based on suodori (dance without costume and hairpieces), in which dancers are dressed casually in kimono and dance in a zashiki (Japanese style tatami room) with folding screens.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 源流となった御殿舞と、能を基本にした静的な舞に、歌舞伎や人形浄瑠璃の要素を加味しており、しっとりとした内面的な舞い方をする。
sen.e: Kamigatamai originated in gotenmai and also based on quiet noh-type dance, with added elements of ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater); the dance is performed in a tranquil manner with an emphasis on inner expression.

Kamigatamai originated in gotenmai and was also based on quiet noh-type dancing, with added elements of ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater); the dance is performed in a tranquil manner with an emphasis on inner expression.

Kamigatamai originated in gotenmai (a kind of traditional Japanese dance) and static dance based on noh-type dancing, with added elements of Kabuki (traditional drama performed by male actors) and ningyo joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater); the dance is performed in a tranquil manner with an emphasis on inner expression.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 歌舞伎舞踊より抽象的で単純化された動きである。
sen.e: Compared to the dances in kabuki, kamigata mai is more abstract and simpler.
Compared to dances in kabuki, kamigata mai is more simple and abstract.
Compared to dances in kabuki, kamigatamai is more simple and abstract.

sen.j: 伴奏に地唄が用いられることから、地唄舞とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Kamigata mai is also called jiuta mai because it is performed to the accompaniment of jiuta (country songs of Kyoto and Osaka regions).
Kamigata mai is also called jiuta mai because it is performed to the accompaniment of jiuta (country songs of Kyoto and Osaka regions).
Kamigatamai is also called jiuta mai because it is performed to the accompaniment of jiuta (country songs of Kyoto and Osaka regions).

sen.j: また上方舞のうち、京都で発展した井上流、篠塚流を京舞（きょうまい）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In kamigata mai, Inoue school and Shinozuka school, which were developed in Kyoto, are specifically called Kyo mai.
In kamigata mai, the Inoue and Shinozuka schools, developed in Kyoto, are specifically called Kyo mai.
In kamigatamai, the Inoue and Shinozuka Schools, developed in Kyoto, are specifically called Kyomai (Kyoto dance).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 本行物（ほんぎょうもの）
sen.e: Hongyo mono
Hongyo mono
Hongyomono (high-toned performance)
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 能楽から借用した、格調が高く重厚味のある作品。
sen.e: Works borrowed from nogaku theater, having elegance and dignity, inculding:
Productuions borrowed from the nogaku theater, having elegance and dignity, include:
Productions borrowed from the nogaku (the art of Noh), having elegance and dignity, include:
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 『葵上』など。
sen.e: Aoi no ue.
Aoi no ue.
"Aoi no ue" (Lady Aoi)
sen.cmt: クォーテーションなどを補足しました。

sen.j: 艶物（つやもの）
sen.e: Tsuyamono
Tsuyamono
Tsuyamono (love story)
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 女舞の色っぽい情緒のある作品。
sen.e: Works that have amorous atmosphere of female dance, including:
Works that have an amorous atmosphere of female dance, include:
Works that have an amorous atmosphere of female dance, include:

sen.j: 『雪』など。
sen.e: Yuki (jiuta)
Yuki (jiuta)
"Yuki" (snow)
sen.cmt: クォーテーションなどを補足しました。

sen.j: 芝居物
sen.e: Shibaimono
Shibaimono
Shibaimono (literally, theatrical entertainment)

sen.j: 歌舞伎舞踊を上方舞に取り入れたもの。
sen.e: Works in which kabuki dances are incorporated into kamigata mai, including:
Productions in which kabuki dances are incorporated into kamigata mai, include:
Productions in which kabuki dances are incorporated into kamigatamai, include:

sen.j: 『江戸土産』『鐘が岬』など。
sen.e: "Edo miyage" and "kanega misaki."
"Edo miyage" and "kanega misaki."
"Edo miyage" (gift from Edo) and "Kanega misaki" (Kanega-misaki cape)
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 作物（さくもの）
sen.e: Sakumono
Sakumono
Sakumono

sen.j: 軽妙でしゃれた味のおどけ物。
sen.e: Works that are witty and humorous, including:
Productions that are witty and humorous, include:
Productions that are witty and humorous, include:

sen.j: 『忘れ唱歌』『三国一』など。
sen.e: "Wasure shoga," and "Sangokuichi."
"Wasure shoga," and "Sangokuichi."
"Wasure Shoga (forgotten songs)) and "Sangokuichi" (best of the world)
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 篠塚流
sen.e: Shinozuka school
Shinozuka school
Shinozuka School

sen.j: 江戸時代後期の文化 (元号)・文政期（1804年-1830年）に、歌舞伎所作事の振付師・篠塚文三郎によって創設された京舞最古の流派。
sen.e: The oldest school of Kyo mai style, which was established in Bunka-Bunsei period (later edo era; 1804-1830) by Bunzaburo SHINOZUKA, a choreographer of kabuki shosagoto (kabuki drama).
The oldest school of Kyo mai style, was established during the Bunka-Bunsei period (later edo era; 1804-1830) by Bunzaburo SHINOZUKA, a choreographer of kabuki shosagoto (kabuki drama).
The oldest school of kyomai, was established from 1804 to 1830 by Bunzaburo SHINOZUKA, a choreographer of kabuki shosagoto (kabuki drama).
sen.cmt: 前出に合わせ和暦をのぞきました。

sen.j: 山村流
sen.e: Yamamura school
Yamamura school
Yamamura School

sen.j: 江戸時代後期の文化三年（1806年）、三代目中村歌右衛門と共に活躍し、当時の上方舞踊界を席巻した上方歌舞伎の振付師・山村友五郎によって創設。
sen.e: A school established in the later edo era (1806) by Yugoro YAMAMURA, a choreographer of kamigata kabuki (kabuki of Kyoto and Osaka region), who worked with Utaemon NAKAMURA the third, dominating the world of kamigata dance at that time.

A school established in the later edo era (1806) by Yugoro YAMAMURA, a choreographer of kamigata kabuki (kabuki of Kyoto and Osaka region), who worked with Utaemon NAKAMURA the third, dominating the world of kamigata dance at that time.

A school established in 1806, the later Edo period, by Yugoro YAMAMURA, a choreographer of kamigata kabuki (kabuki of Kyoto and Osaka region), who worked with Utaemon NAKAMURA the third, dominating the world of kamigata dance at that time.

sen.j: 舞の品の良さから商家の子女の習い事として隆盛を極めた。
sen.e: The school became very popular because the elegant dance style was preferred by merchant families to have their children learn the dance.
The school became very popular because the elegant dance style was preferred by merchant families who wanted to have their children learn the dance.
The school became very popular because the elegant dance style was preferred by merchant families who wanted to have their children learn the dance.

sen.j: 楳茂都流（うめもとりゅう）
sen.e: Umemoto school
Umemoto school
Umemoto School

sen.j: 1841年に楳茂都扇性が創流。
sen.e: A school created by Sensho UMEMOTO in 1841.
A school created by Sensho UMEMOTO in 1841.
A school created by Sensho UMEMOTO in 1841.

sen.j: 井上流
sen.e: Inoue school
Inoue school
Inoue School

sen.j: 江戸時代末期に井上サトが創流。
sen.e: A school created by Sato INOUE in the end of Edo era.
A school created by Sato INOUE at the end of the Edo era.
A school created by Sato INOUE at the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 祇園甲部の芸妓・舞妓による流派。
sen.e: A school of Geisha and Maiko in Gion Kobu District.
A school of Geisha and Maiko in Gion Kobu District.

A school of geigi (a woman who gives fun with a song, a dance or a music instrument at a feast) and maiko (apprentice geisha (Japanese professional female entertainer at drinking party in Edo)) in Gion Kobu region.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 都をどりが有名。
sen.e: The school is famous for Miyako odori.
The school is famous for Miyako odori.
The school is famous for Miyako Odori (dance performance held in April by geisha and maiko in Kyoto's Gion region).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 井上八千代四世 井上八千代は一代の舞の名手で人間国宝認定を受けた。
sen.e: Yachiyo INOUE the fourth: Yachiyo INOUE was one of the best dancer of the age and certified as the holder of Important Intangible Cultural Property (also called "Living National Treasure," certified by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology).

Yachiyo INOUE the fourth: Yachiyo INOUE was one of the best dancers of the age and was certified as the holder of an Important Intangible Cultural Property (also called "Living National Treasure," certified by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science, and Technology).

Yachiyo INOUE the fourth: Yachiyo INOUE was one of the best dancers of the age and was certified as the holder of an Important Intangible Cultural Property (also called "Living National Treasure," certified by the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science, and Technology).

sen.j: 吉村流
sen.e: Yoshimura school
Yoshimura school
Yoshimura School

sen.j: 江戸時代末期に京都の京都御所に出仕した狂言師が始めた御殿舞を源流とし、 明治初期に吉村ふじによって創設された流派。
sen.e: Yoshimura school originated in gotenmai, a traditional Japanese dance style developed by Kyogen performers who served at Kyoto Imerial Palace in Kyoto in the end of edo era, and established in early Meiji era by Fuji YOSHIMURA.

The Yoshimura school originated in gotenmai, a traditional Japanese dance style developed by Kyogen performers who served at the Imperial Palace in Kyoto at the end of the edo era, and was established in early Meiji era by Fuji YOSHIMURA.

The School originated in gotenmai, a traditional Japanese dance style developed by kyogen (farce played during a No play cycle) performers who served at the Imperial Palace in Kyoto at the end of the Edo period, and was established in early Meiji period by Fuji YOSHIMURA.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。edo →Edoに変更しました。

sen.j: 四代目吉村雄輝は人間国宝認定、文化功労者選定。
sen.e: Yuki YOSHIMURA the fourth was certified as the holder of Important Intangible Cultural Property as well as awarded with the Person of Cultural Merit.
Yuki YOSHIMURA the fourth was certified as the holder of an Important Intangible Cultural Property as well as being awarded with the title of a Person of Cultural Merit.
Yuki YOSHIMURA the fourth was certified as the holder of an Important Intangible Cultural Property as well as being awarded with the title of a Person of Cultural Merit.
